docs.lead_paragraph: NEVER mind the yen, the ruble, the dress. They've all been mentioned as contributors to the latest bouts of queasiness in the long-running bull market, but sorting out the causes can take investors only so far. For many people with savings tied up in stocks, it may be time to make defensive maneuvers to protect gains and help minimize the risk of losses.

headline.main: Have You Been Looking for Shelter in All the Wrong Places?
headline.kicker: STORM CLOUDS OVER WALL STREET: THE HAVENS

docs.abstract: Article on defensive measures that investors can take to protect themselves from stock market downturns; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN parts and pockets of Africa, there is an extra season every year. It is called the hunger season. That is when, said Martha Carey of Doctors Without Borders, ''people forage for food -- they strip wild plants, they dig for fish in mud flats.'' In the Sudan, it is the hunger season and they are slaughtering their cows. ''Cows are their last insurance policy,'' she said. ''They cannot be replaced. After that, they have nothing.'' The world's attention has been focused on Africa lately because of the bombings of American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, and because of the extreme suffering of the Sudanese, who are again on the run from yet another cycle of war between a Muslim north and a traditionalist and Christian south. But a million other stories of deprivation and intractable hunger just a notch less severe never get told because they are so common.

headline.main: The World: Hardscrabble; Where the Hunger Season Is Part of Life

docs.abstract: Persistent hunger in many parts of Africa described; 35 of 45 countries at bottom of UN's Human Development Index are in Africa; photos; life expectancy on most of continent hovers between 40 and 50 years, few people have access to health care, clean water or toilets, and daily caloric intake is third or more below that of Mexico or China; decline in many countries since independence noted (S

docs.lead_paragraph: BIG OIL A British Amoco In the biggest foreign takeover ever of an American company, British Petroleum announced that it would buy Amoco (the name once stood for American Oil Company) for $48.2 billion, eclipsing Daimler-Benz's $40.5 billion deal for Chrysler. The agreement, subject to regulatory and shareholder approval, would create the world's third-largest multinational oil company in net income, after Exxon and Royal Dutch/Shell. The combination is expected to create a formidable competitor. B.P. is known for its skill at finding oil in the North Sea and elsewhere around the world, while Amoco's strength is in refining its products into oil and chemicals and distributing them to consumers. (Article, page 10.) BELL ATLANTIC Score One for Workers Proclaiming victory, 73,000 members of the Communications Workers of America ended a two-day strike and returned to work at Bell Atlantic. The company, which serves telephone customers from Maine to Virginia, agreed to guarantee job security to its union workers -- even in digital technologies only now being developed. Experts in labor relations called it a significant union victory. Kate Bronfenbrenner, director of labor education research at Cornell University, said workers in other industries were likely to be inspired by Bell Atlantic's agreement to phase out a nonunion customer service operation in Virginia.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Aug. 9 front-page article on the lack of health insurance coverage for nearly one-sixth of the population demonstrates anew the incompatibility of health with commercial interests. A sick person should not be a source of profit for a business.
docs.abstract: Alfred Gutmann letter on Aug 9, 11 and 12 articles holds health care is incompatible with commercial interests

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Dr. Neal L. Cohen, New York City's Health Commissioner, seems stymied by the decline in infant mortality rates in New York City despite an increase in the uninsured (news article, Aug. 12). Aside from the many non-medical influences on infant deaths, one component of the decline seems evident: a large system of municipal hospital and ambulatory care sites that serve all women and infants regardless of insurance or immigration status.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: An Aug. 9 front-page article and Aug. 12 letter responses note the 41 million Americans without health insurance. How many of those people cannot afford health insurance? How many can but instead spend their money in other ways? So far, no statistics have analyzed health care needs this way.
docs.abstract: Dave Green letter on Aug 9 article and Aug 12 letters questions how many of Americans without health insurance can afford it but choose to spend money in other ways; drawing8
